meanings.definition: Make (guilt or an offense) seem less serious or more forgivable.
meanings.sent1: She extenuated her mistake by apologizing sincerely.
meanings.sent2: The lawyer tried to extenuate the crime by highlighting the defendant's difficult upbringing.
meanings.sent3: He tried to extenuate his lateness by blaming it on traffic.
meanings.sent4: Her tears could not extenuate the gravity of her betrayal.
meanings.sent5: The heartfelt apology did little to extenuate the pain caused by the betrayal.

meanings.sent1: The illness extenuated his once strong physique.
meanings.sent2: The harsh conditions in the prison camp extenuated the prisoners.
meanings.sent3: The extreme diet plan only served to extenuate her health issues.
meanings.sent4: The relentless training regimen extenuated his muscles to the point of exhaustion.
meanings.sent5: The lack of proper nutrition extenuated her frailty even further.

meanings.definition: Make (something) thinner or weaker by reducing its thickness or density.
meanings.sent1: The constant use of the old rope extenuated it over time.
meanings.sent2: The harsh weather conditions extenuated the wooden beams of the house.
meanings.sent3: The repeated washing extenuated the fabric of the shirt, making it almost transparent.
meanings.sent4: The intense heat extenuated the metal, causing it to warp.
meanings.sent5: The erosion from the river extenuated the rocks along its banks.
